question_text: Explain how combustion temperature affects the volatilization-condensation mechanism of trace elements in coal fly ash formation, and analyze how this mechanism influences the distribution of Group II elements across different particle sizes according to the provided paper.
standard_answer: Combustion temperature plays a critical role in the volatilization-condensation mechanism during coal fly ash formation. At high combustion temperatures (typically between 400°C and 1500°C), mineral elements undergo phase transformations where certain elements volatilize and subsequently condense onto finer fly ash particles as the flue gases cool. This mechanism creates distinct enrichment patterns based on element classification. According to the volatilization-condensation theory, Group II elements (As, Cd, Mu, Pb, Sb, and Se), defined as 'chalcophiles', display increasing concentration with decreasing particle size due to their volatilization behavior at combustion temperatures and subsequent condensation onto the surfaces of smaller fly ash particles. In contrast, Group I elements (Al, Ca, Fe, K, Mg, Na, and Ti), classified as 'lithophiles', show little or no enrichment in smaller particles, while Group III elements (Be, Cu, Ni, V, and Co) exhibit intermediate behavior with some enrichment in smaller particles but to a lesser extent than Group II elements. The combustion temperature directly affects the extent of mineral element volatilization, with higher temperatures promoting greater enrichment of these volatile elements on smaller particles through this condensation mechanism.
